4E8E61A56E3F42AC9C1A4A2D768007F8.description: Discuss the role and importance of language and sharing of stories in the preservation and evolution of cultural identity (e.g., treaty education outcome SI10, indicator -- imagine what society would look like today if all treaty obligations had been completely fulfilled and what it could look like into the future).

1E7F7A06AC174316828602A44F4A6433.description: Listen to a traditional or contemporary Métis story (e.g., invited guests, online) and respond through one or more art forms.

5EE23F70830D4F629438C107006AD43C.description: Investigate how Indigenous traditional knowledge is transmitted (e.g., oral, digital, multimedia) and/or influential in drama and theatre work.

45506604D7394C19A48CAEC9043117C1.description: Engage, where possible, with an Elder, Knowledge Keeper or First Nations storyteller to hear stories and learn about protocols concerning the telling and gifting of traditional stories.

96764333147C46EBAEBD9E407514C701.description: Examine how stories may be used for different purposes (e.g., to explain how the world works, how to behave, oral and/or written histories).

667D7398EDD84ADAA81481F12838D746.description: Discuss the significance of oral transmission of Métis, First Nations, and/or Inuit history and family stories.

E54272A5C8FE43F39338D7689A432EB3.description: Tell own story (e.g., drawing on memories, cultural background, personal experiences, family history).

67444FC5A1314CE5B2750B6617A9E587.description: Research the role of storytelling and oral history in an Indigenous culture, past or present, and, respecting protocols, use this learning to inspire own stories and dramatic work.

AF6519C64AF34018AEC36ACD4BD083A2.description: Reflect on own interactions with forms of dramatic work most enjoyed, and describe ways these choices are connected to personal perspectives and/or experiences.

06AF9CD73785428FB602079EEBDF3E08.description: Reflect on the ways that viewing or reading dramatic work has challenged own views or beliefs (e.g., climate change, gender and sexual diversity, unfulfilled treaty promises, interpersonal relationships).

7D67E7D41F8D494B9CFC188A420BC6D6.description: Gather an audience’s reaction to a dramatic work through discussion or written means.

D51BFBEFDA09413BB365A53AB666942B.description: Respond to dramatic works, student created or other, and reflect on the impact on self and audience.

2BDDD2A61D9C462E9D2F16BBB601EB76.description: Examine how drama represents human experience and impacts individuals.

BE9C4842AECB44978DCFAFB32EA7A4C2.description: Reflect on how drama and theatre performances relate to a specific time, place and culture (e.g., examine dramatic arts and theatre traditions and practices from the homelands of newcomer students).

8532989EE3B04B47927A6EADA1DFB0C0.description: Create a timeline of theatre traditions around the world.

84A4CEFA449A41EBB04B337CA62390F8.description: Recognize that artistic practices are sometimes specific to a treaty territory, cultural and/or language group in Saskatchewan and Canada.

0053CB98B65C4BDFB954C816AE599233.description: Discuss connections between Indigenous artistic traditions (e.g., song, dance, stories) and the land, identities and worldviews (e.g., treaty education outcome SI10 - examine the spirit and intent of Treaties and investigate [through drama work] the extent to which they have been fulfilled).

57F98FC155494535A330F148B0F96563.description: Examine dramatic performance and theatre history from a variety of traditions.

DAA2B107B46A4D3AB3B9E1929DC91B46.description: Volunteer or job shadow, where possible, in a professional or community theatre or theatre school.

3B305F472986450EBCDC4215C64923F0.description: Reflect on own skills and experiences and represent them (e.g., written or videotaped artist bio, headshot, cover letter).

BF9BA7DC96004890993D4F606CF47E35.description: Examine how artists represent their training/experiences in an artist biography.

52B6F0F11CB840909BAD12964BC4C202.description: Explore the training options available through mentorship, university, college, workshops and specific courses

8F599E16E32945FDA3BCB19C4408143E.description: Identify theatre artists, groups and performance venues in Saskatchewan, and examine various paths available to work in these careers.

4120ACC3DCC2416ABD342C3899A4A6E0.description: Investigate educational opportunities for theatre artists in Saskatchewan, and examine possible careers and training paths.

7E3F9991E1E94627853A8332A5DE53E3.description: Identify various stage and audience seating arrangements (e.g., thrust, proscenium, in the round, open-air, promenade, site-specific) and consider how each affects both the actors’ performances and the audience’s response.

BC8F6B1A4E5048F39A257B61797C805A.description: Identify the purpose of various conventions (e.g., dimming of lights, actor’s entrance, blackouts, curtain calls) and how they impact the audience experience.

1CB4088BC73A49FF91FAB0E0D7AEFA4C.description: Compare the social and political climate of the time in which a play was created and first produced with later productions, and evaluate the play using the language of theatre.

E2B08EC526034818BE7DA6CF12936C4D.description: Analyze directorial decisions made in a contemporary production including the casting, staging and design choices.

5C153B2D2F5749DC88F4A7E91861D3CF.description: Describe, analyze and interpret, using the language of theatre, a selected piece of dramatic work, withholding judgement while formulating an informed opinion.

E9AAAE27F2D740759D2D89E7CA332710.description: Research the context of the place and time in which a selected play or piece of dramatic work was written, including, for example: an overview of the social, political and cultural climate of the times in which a selected play was written and performed; biographical information about the playwright and/or reviews of other plays by the playwright; a reading of other plays written during the same time period; and a description of the expectations and moods of audiences during the years of the play's creation and productions.

81E65158895546E4B3CD4FD2B0408A5E.description: View a live or recorded performance and discuss the role of the audience in various types of performances (e.g., conventional Western theatre, children’s theatre, forum theatre, site-specific theatre).

64D508ABC538411D8E277CAAA3E467AF.description: Respond critically, using appropriate theatrical language, to student and/or professional work and genres.

06B05B8210DB4DBF981D30AF637CA7A8.description: Critical/Responsive (CR) Goal: Students will respond to artistic expressions of Saskatchewan, Canadian, and international artists using critical thinking, research, creativity, and collaborative inquiry.

EC038C26E910446D813F3BE8C8722D3B.description: Assess the strengths of the performance and reflect on the collaborative approaches, challenges, and individual contributions encountered in the creative process.

543B108615AB4440807AFB0533EDBB6B.description: Consider and apply safe and proper use of tools, technologies and materials (e.g., lights, sound systems, makeup and skin care, set and/or prop construction).

C26E84A3C87446AD89531C0A7750C465.description: Consider how various spaces impact performance potential and audience response or interaction (e.g., theatre in the round, site-specific theatre, auditorium, outdoors, classroom).

1F3C6E41E4FF408C87D270B455727917.description: Identify individual theatrical roles (e.g., actor, theatre technician, writer, dramaturge, director, designers, critic, stage manager, administrator, choreographer, musical director) and discuss how they work together effectively for performance.

28C684FD372746F1B406D30BB6BEF4CA.description: Sustain role during various situations that may occur while performing (e.g., unexpected laughter, stage mishap, technical trouble) and discuss solutions for future occurrences.

AD76FC84136C4191BA5B91BBC844F5E4.description: Use the language of theatre effectively in performance (e.g., stage directions, lighting cues, blocking).

6AC3C9C9B8BD470BB57CD73B5A815BA6.description: Present and sustain a performance for an audience (e.g., peers, invited guests, public).

2409961C0C684B70A60807F47F342626.description: Discuss interpersonal processes (e.g., negotiation, shared power, shared responsibility, collaboration, consensus, group skills, community making, ensemble building) required to create devised drama or theatre pieces, and reflect on the successes and challenges encountered in own work.

E3D75E398AD84257A33DFC00AE6CAA6B.description: Create a devised play and/or scene through collective processes that may include: brainstorming, idea generating, researching, exploring, improvising, writing, journaling, storyboarding, editing, refining, framing the story with theatre devices, rehearsing and presenting.

BDE50F3554E9433E8F9562AEE7AF18C2.description: Explore the ways that identity, personal experiences and worldview shape creative work.

C9DDC3E519834918AD15A110015E1C17.description: Investigate a creative process for building a play or scene from devised material.

5B1C43F64D4440898DB7B777EC7C6F16.description: Discuss how empathy is fostered through experimentation with voice and perspective.

96CAAE18A9B7452BB21E9D71A828BA9D.description: Adapt a scene from the perspective of a supporting character or a character not present.

F6B02E76CC4A41F08C930DE580A23830.description: Create a scene that demonstrates at least two opposing voices.

FD42265ACB734C16BA638F6EC5EF3EA8.description: Demonstrate perspective and voice through the performance of an original or published monologue.

3629EDAB13C941EF878A336C772EE2A7.description: Use interviews as a source to create a scene that uses artistic voice to represent a perspective (e.g., authority figure, newcomer, family member, Métis activist, community leader, friend).

BA6A37943BC84AB19A4A125B8617423D.description: Demonstrate the purposeful use of artistic voice to communicate perspective.

39FFCA0BC8434FF988A75181C79AA36A.description: Assess the strengths of the drama work and/or performance and reflect on the collaborative approaches, challenges, and individual contributions encountered in the creative process.

63CABCF5BCD64CA6877963D4764C8304.description: Discuss and reflect on ways that selected genres, styles and performance practices can be adapted and incorporated in own work (e.g., using masks and story to examine a contemporary social issue, using mime and expressionist conventions to represent the protagonist’s internal state).

6661EF18B1B340D29A3A55FA22293F23.description: Examine a range of genres, styles and performance practices (e.g., Métis and First Nations stories and culturally-based performance traditions, comedy, tragedy, mime, naturalism, Francophone and Fransaskois performance and theatre history, expressionism, modernism) and, respecting cultural protocols that may exist for specific communities, use selected ideas as inspiration for own dramatic work.

F8EA48D884534E21BC856BC3E63B1535.description: Explore a variety of genres, styles and performance practices.

62C059D3EAC34A3BABE2E282939D099A.description: Explore connections and ways to expand upon inspirations and departure points.

BFE53494185C40D7A311C91989CD7514.description: Generate ideas for exploration through improvisation and devised scene-work

FEF4F183AA8C4905B6034A5D12FB2FDB.description: Use personal narratives to explore concepts of memory, history and experiences relating to identity (e.g., cultural, gender expression, urban or rural perspectives, pop culture influences, sexual orientation, social status, youth or elder, immigrant).

80AB9D9EB37A45888C1EE1B2F4A85D2F.description: Investigate inspiration and departure points for dramatic work.

5A13325D4FDA402CAC39164F267E731A.description: Creative/Productive (CP) Goal: Students will inquire, create, and communicate through dance, drama, music and visual art.
